body: Sorry for missing this in the previous PR. LGTM.

Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 8 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- *[sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/BeamRecordFactory.java, line 53 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4204#-L3EaapDvP4fffX3Ri73:-L3Eo8f8HYnSACB9u_cC:b9tm155) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/40c4ff167947ec3addaf9f281ff919e80f97ceb4/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/BeamRecordFactory.java#L53)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
Recommended pattern for classes like this: A single private constructor that takes all the arguments. Then for each way of building one, have a `public static` method with a useful name. So this constructor would be `default()` and the one below would be `forRecordTypeFactory(...)`, or something like that.
Agree. Hidden the constructors, added `BeamRecordFactory.createDefault()`. --- *[sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/BeamRecordFactory.java, line 81 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4204#-L3Eb11oH6FUBuXqfPWb:-L3EoM6PRJnMwb3aLRTD:b89ektd) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/40c4ff167947ec3addaf9f281ff919e80f97ceb4/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/BeamRecordFactory.java#L81)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
Incidentally, `BeamRecord` should also have clear named factory methods instead of public constructor.
I agree. But there appears to be more than 70 usages of the constructors. I'd prefer to do this in another PR. --- *[sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/DefaultRecordTypeFactory.java, line 30 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4204#-L3EbCV00DR3T1uct2YB:-L3EocMgChtEmvJG4VtS:b-6u42jz) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/40c4ff167947ec3addaf9f281ff919e80f97ceb4/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/DefaultRecordTypeFactory.java#L30)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
Can you describe what its behavior is like? Why is it the default? Also - is it `@Internal`?
Updated the javadoc with this. Short version: This factory creates record types from the list of getters. Record types are represented by `BeamRecordType` which essentially is a `List>`. Getters are represented by a `List`. So the factory creates former from the latter. Normally you can do this by mapping java types of the getters to coders using `CoderRegistry` or even manual mapping. This is what this factory does. Problem with SQL is that it uses `java.sq.Types` to describe types of the record. It keeps this information in `BeamRecordSqlType` in addition to field names and coders. And it is referenced across a bunch of SQL classes. To map the `java.sql.Types` to coders we then need a custom mapping, which is done in a SQL-specific implementation of this interface. --- *[sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/package-info.java, line 22 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4204#-L3EYCva7WmOEvE3Cm3S:-L3Eu79-x2YuT282Tsf3:bhjkvuv) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/40c4ff167947ec3addaf9f281ff919e80f97ceb4/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/package-info.java#L22)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
Is there a special reason to make a new package? It does mean there might be things that are `public` but are not intended for users. So what we do in that case is mark them `@Internal` and also make a big bold comment that says "For internal use only. No backwards compatibility guarantees." Of if things that are public are what you want and you made stuff package private where appropriate, that's great. And the other thing to do with the package is to set up static analysis with `@DefaultAnnotation(NonNull.class)`
The parent `values` package seems to contain mostly value types around `PCollection` with almost no other logic. Adding a ton of reflection and code-generation code there didn't seem right, they would become noise in the `values` package. Haven't thought about `@Internal` until now, thanks for suggestion. Updated: * Combined `org.apache.beam.sdk.values.reflect` and `org.apache.beam.sdk.values.reflect.field`; * Made everything package-private except: * `RecordTypeFactory` interface. Used in SQL. Marked it as `@Internal`; * `FieldValueGetter` interface. Used by the above factory in SQL. Marked as `@Internal`; * `BeamRecordFactory`. Is the only functional class accessed outside of the package. Marked as `@Internal`; --- *[sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/field/FieldValueGetter.java, line 29 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4204#-L3EZLmdr-9mklDOvgfv:-L3FCCUNVt42--OR1C7O:b8eqibd) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/40c4ff167947ec3addaf9f281ff919e80f97ceb4/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/field/FieldValueGetter.java#L29)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
While this is a pretty harmless interface, I think it should still be `@Internal`. I assume that SQL and the new DoFn code will perhaps interface with it so it will have to be public no matter what package, yea?
I agree. Updated --- *[sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/field/GeneratedGetterFactory.java, line 69 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4204#-L3EZie0jOzoyGC_VSKx:-L3FCG2EkAZclt5X9lkV:b-tp6to4) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/40c4ff167947ec3addaf9f281ff919e80f97ceb4/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/field/GeneratedGetterFactory.java#L69)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
With the DoFn stuff, we had issue where the stacktrace had pseudo-random bits in it so aggregated errors across workers didn't work. I think these bits are expected to be correct-by-construction and never allowed to throw exceptions, yes?
Hm, haven't really thought about this. Generated code itself doesn't throw but technically nothing stops the underlying getters from doing so. Do you have any ideas on how to handle this better? --- *[sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/field/package-info.java, line 22 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4204#-L3E_3p8Q6D5s1nl-tU5:-L3FDiVCQm0KsniJcM58:b-13mbq) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/40c4ff167947ec3addaf9f281ff919e80f97ceb4/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/reflect/field/package-info.java#L22)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
Is there a benefit to even more deeply nesting packages? I'd keep it a bit more flat just to make things easy to find and make it most flexible in terms of managing public/private.
Combined with parent package. --- *[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/BeamRecordSqlType.java, line 90 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4204#-L3EaA3IceENKUiKC4QU:-L3FDsMK5JGcqclPCx7I:b-g3lvlm) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/40c4ff167947ec3addaf9f281ff919e80f97ceb4/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/BeamRecordSqlType.java#L90)):*
Previously, kennknowles (Kenn Knowles) wrote…
Is this class for internal use only or also do users interact with it? It should either be `@Internal` and with lots of caveats or should have javadoc on public factor methods like this one. Etc throughout (not actually related to this particular pull request)
Added javadoc. It's public. Until we have the code generation wired up the only way to create a record is to manually create a `BeamRecordSqlType` and then use it to create records. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4204)*
Should I force push a squashed commit or should we stick to these 2?
I'll squash when merging, just waiting on tests.
LGTM, ping me when you make the changes.
LGTM. I will merge after tests pass.

Thanks @jkff for the update. Waiting @lukecwik green light to merge. In the meantime, I'm investigating Maven build issue on master (the `jenkins-precommit` Maven profile adds all runners in the classpath, causing issues).
You should also squash to reduce the "commits noise".
By the way, I added a method to define the batch size in #4458 . You can take a look if you want. I will try to merge pretty fast, you can rebase your branch on this one.
I refactored the code and created an abstract super class for both write operations, and thereby also removed the use of the batch size in WriteIterable.
I'll rebase my PR on your changes as soon as I can (as far as I know, I can't currently base it on your  branch as it is in your fork, so I'll have to wait until it's merged).

Test failure is https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3492 which I have upgraded to "blocker" since it muddies our test signal.

Please update the bigtable version in `build.gradle`

Also, does this change the version of Netty, tcnative, protobuf, or gRPC that is required? If so, then we can't take this change in without those pieces being shaded away.

I updated the `gradle.build` version.  This should not affect the maven dependencies, since the pom.xml explicitly includes specific versions of grpc, netty and protobuf.  Gradle looks like it does the same.

Is there a timeline for upgrading grpc to something newer?  1.2.0 was released march 2017.
No timeline, just this feature request: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3098

On the other hand, it is very nice to have an integration test that actually tests what our users will do. Without passing args to `main` we aren't actually testing the example as written in the tutorial.

It is actually the layer of indirection through `TestPipeline` that is the problem. We should be able to launch `main` with test args directly.
Testing the `main` function isn't that important, testing a PTransform is much easier for a user to understand and integrates with test frameworks more naturally.
Note that this change also addresses https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3510.

Yeah if you can avoid reconstructing the queue, that will certainly simplify things. Please be careful though cause blocking queues are prone to deadlocks if a consumer can ever block on a producer (e.g. if consumer is getting a lock before taking an item from the queue, but the consumer holds the lock while trying to add the item to a full queue).
Superceded by #4453, which is built on top of the submitted components.

Because I can't seem to comment in the same thread: rmannibucau 3 days ago  •  edited  Member
If you check the instantiation, it depends on the commitbundle which changes so we cant cache it, can we?

I'm still not entirely sure what you mean, but the processor and the input elements should be separable. In `ProcessFn` we do so by setting the bundle-dependent state each time through the `createEvaluator` call - the `ProcessFn` itself doesn't contain any per-input dependent state that isn't explicitly set during the creation of the evaluator, so it'll be mutated to an appropriate state for each new bundle.

Previously, rangadi (Raghu Angadi) wrote…
The UnboundedSource interface is somewhat similar to hadoop. split() method passes in 'desiredNumSplits' which is a hint from the runner to the source. The source can try to obey or return any number splits that makes sense for the source. Runner decides how to map those splits into its internal processing parallelism. In that sense does 'maxSourceParallism' directly influence 'desiredNumSplits'? How it works in : Streaming applications in Dataflow: Its 'desiredNumSplits' is based on max number of cores the jobs is configured (due to autoscaling, actually number of cores might be fewer). If the source returns more splits than suggested, I think Dataflow tries to run all of the splits in parallel (need to check if there is a limit).
@rangadi you're right about maxSourceParallism, which is used to set the "desiredNumSplits" so the splits are bounded by this number. In samza, this will decide the number of tasks for a job. What I was saying (I think Kenneth meant the same) is that it'll be super nice that BEAM provides an API for the source to split into a default number, like the number of partitions in Kafka. So as a user, he doesn't need to bother finding out the number of each input kafka topic parittions when he runs the job. For LinkedIn, this is very valuable since a Kafka topic might have different partitions in different fabrics, so a default will be very helpful to the users. That's also the behavior in Samza today if the user doesn't provide a customized grouper of partitions: each partition becomes a task (or a split in this case). --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4340#-:-L3VMcD5P9bNfYMrD6ra:b-j3iy8p)*

Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 3 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- *[sdks/java/build-tools/src/main/resources/beam/findbugs-filter.xml, line 52 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4453#-L3Yl2VQepVna3F6EuY7:-L3Yl2VQepVna3F6EuY8:bn95efx) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/c0acaafc9015695c940f732ea19e287bd75e90d3/sdks/java/build-tools/src/main/resources/beam/findbugs-filter.xml#L52)):* > ```XML > > > > ``` If you are feeling generous, since this line was touched, move it to a localized warning. --- *[sdks/java/fn-execution/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/fn/data/BeamFnDataGrpcMultiplexer.java, line 105 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4453#-L3YlnuVbZpU0SWA3gfD:-L3YlnuVbZpU0SWA3gfE:b-7p76) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/c0acaafc9015695c940f732ea19e287bd75e90d3/sdks/java/fn-execution/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/fn/data/BeamFnDataGrpcMultiplexer.java#L105)):* > ```Java > for (CompletableFuture> receiver : > ImmutableList.copyOf(consumers.values())) { > if (receiver.isDone()) { > ``` This is a race condition. It could become done between this line and cancelation. Cancelation anyhow already is idempotent and checks if the future is already done. So I'll convert this conditional to a comment. --- *[sdks/java/fn-execution/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/fn/data/SettableFutureFutureInboundDataClient.java, line 24 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4453#-L3Ym43URt0ENZ4pjEiG:-L3Ym43URt0ENZ4pjEiH:b-ptegol) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/c0acaafc9015695c940f732ea19e287bd75e90d3/sdks/java/fn-execution/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/fn/data/SettableFutureFutureInboundDataClient.java#L24)):* > ```Java > > /** An {@link InboundDataClient} backed by a {@link SettableFuture}. */ > class SettableFutureFutureInboundDataClient implements InboundDataClient { > ``` FutureFuture --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4453#-:-L3YmL3ZrvQKt7779rLS:b-1mhh1t)*
@akedin has been doing some refactors to variance, so may be interested in seeing this too
Hi @jkff @pawel-kaczmarczyk @jbonofre @iemejia , can you please take a look?

Thanks for the review. The reason that I want to add the writeIterable method, is that it gives me more control over the actual batch size being written to the database. In my development environment, the records were always written in batches of 1 when using the original write method (even though the default batch size of 1,000 was set), which for Cloud Spanner is a really slow way of writing the data. I have not been able to find any method to control the actual batch size reliably.
Whether the default of 1,000 records per batch would be appropriate specifically for Cloud Spanner, depends on the size of the rows. Cloud Spanner has a maximum commit size of 100MB, which means that the 1,000 limit could be too low for tables with few (and small) columns, while it could be too high for tables with a large number of columns. As Jdbc is a generic standard, I guess it's hard to have one size that really fits them all, although a default of 1,000 sounds reasonable to me.

It sounds like the original issue is that you were unexpectedly getting bundles of size 1 element which is indeed too small, and definitely has more performance issues than just JDBC batching. I'd love to know more about your pipeline to investigate why that would be the case (were you using the Dataflow runner or a different one? What does the pipeline look like?)

You can try to resolve that by applying the original JdbcIO.write() to just what you did here in your test + a Flatten.iterables() (in general, c.apply(JdbcIO.writeIterables()) == c.apply(Flatten.iterables()).apply(JdbcIO.write())).

I was using the DirectRunner. I'll try your suggestion to see if it makes any difference.
My Pipeline was the standard WordCount example, but writing the words to a Cloud Spanner database instead of text files. ([https://github.com/olavloite/spanner-beam-example/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/examples/WordCount.java](https://github.com/olavloite/spanner-beam-example/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/examples/WordCount.java))

Oh I see. Direct runner indeed uses bundles of size 1 key after a grouping operation (and CountWords in that example is a grouping operation). My suggestion is likely to help - please let me know if it doesn't.
It would help if you could provide a code snippet that doesn't work without this.
Good idea, I documented the reason for requiring DirectRunner (for those tests that weren't already explicitly tests of the DirectRunner).

And it turns out since editing in the web/ and creating a pull request doesn't do what I expected I'm going to need to send this again when I've sorted out my local development story.
